items.title: The translucent Beats Studio Buds Plus are half off
items.raw:
Noise-canceling earbuds are great productivity tools, blocking out noisy roommates and busy coffee shops so you can focus on studying or work. While there are a number of great options these days, few are as eye-catching like the translucent Beats Studio Buds Plus. And right now, you can buy the stylish wireless earbuds for just $84.99 from Woot ‚Äî a 50 percent discount and the best price we‚Äôve seen outside of a brief drop to $63 earlier in June.
The wireless earbuds are some of our favorites, and not just because they look cool. Despite the fact Apple owns Beats, they play well with both iOS and Android devices. They don‚Äôt support every software feature ‚Äî like Apple‚Äôs automatic device switching ‚Äî but they still offer perks like one-tap pairing and integration with each platform‚Äôs respective Find My networks. Their sound quality also comes close to matching the latest AirPods Pro, and their active noise-cancellation does a good job of tuning out distractions ‚Äî even if it‚Äôs not as powerful as Apple‚Äôs premium earbuds.
The Beats Studio Buds Plus are also comfortable, arriving with four swappable silicone ear tips. You also get IPX4 water resistance, as well as up to six hours of battery life on a single charge with ANC enabled. While we wish they also offered wireless charging and multipoint Bluetooth connectivity, all in all they‚Äôre a well-rounded option that can help you focus while looking good ‚Äî especially if you own both iOS and Android devices.
Read our Beats Studio Buds Plus review.
Beats Studio Buds Plus
The Beats Studio Buds Plus offer better sound and noise cancellation than the original pair, and they now come in a unique translucent color option. Read our review.

Where to Buy:

 $169.95 $84.95 at Woot
 $169.95 $99.95 at Amazon
 $169.95 $99.99 at Best Buy



Some more ways to save
You can buy the Hoto Flashlight Lite for $31.99 ($8 off) at Amazon, which matches its best price to date. The portable flashlight offers multiple adjustable brightness settings that reach up to 1,000-lumens. It also supports USB-C recharges and sports a useful zooming feature that lets you switch between a floodlight and a spotlight mode, which reaches up to 200 meters when focused.
The latest Blink Video Doorbell is on sale for $39.99 ($30 off) at Amazon, Best Buy, and Target, which is its second-best price to date and $10 shy of its all-time low. The basic video doorbell is a solid upgrade over the original, adding a wide 150-degree field of view, a better 1440p image resolution, and a 1:1 aspect ratio so you get a head-to-toe view of whoever is on your porch. The doorbell also comes with a Sync Module so you can store clips locally and, if you pay for $3 monthly subscription, adds person detection.
As a part of its new Labor Day sale, MasterClass is offering new and returning subscribers up to 50 percent off one year of its annual membership through September 1st. The membership typically starts at $120, so that means you‚Äôll be paying as low as $60 instead. The deal also applies to higher tiers, which grant access to offline mode and streaming on multiple devices. The platform offers over 200 classes taught by world leaders, celebrities, and various experts across tech, sports, business, entertainment, health, games, food, and more.

items.title: Silksong is out soon, and indie games are getting out of the way
items.raw:
Yesterday, Hollow Knight: Silksong developers Team Cherry announced a September 4th release date for the long-awaited game, and indie developers are announcing delays to get out of the way of the launch. Silksong is a full sequel to the excellent Hollow Knight and is currently the most wishlisted game on Steam, so it‚Äôs likely going to be very popular when it‚Äôs finally available.
Panik Arcade, which was set to release its ‚Äúhellish gambling roguelike‚Äù CloverPit on September 3rd, has pushed the game‚Äôs launch to September 26th. ‚ÄúWe poured our hearts into our little game so of course we want to give it the best possible shot,‚Äù Panik Arcade says. ‚ÄúWe hope you can understand ‚Äî we‚Äôll use the extra time of course to polish the game even further and we hope for your support at launch either way.‚Äù


üö®GAME DELAY üö®
due to Silksong (can‚Äôt wait to play) launching just a day after CloverPit, we decided to delay our release
our new release date is 26th Sept
we poured our hearts into our little game, so we want to give it the best possible shot. thanks for understanding!! pic.twitter.com/QwKwBrBuFJ
‚Äî Panik Arcade üïπÔ∏è making CloverPit üçíüé∞ (@PanikArcade) August 22, 2025


Talegames, which was planning to launch the adventure RPG Faeland out of early access on September 9th, is postponing the release and plans to share a new date soon. ‚ÄúThis wasn‚Äôt an easy decision,‚Äù Talegames says. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve poured years of work and love into Faeland, and we want to make sure it arrives at a time when it can receive the attention and care it deserves.‚Äù¬†


Our v1.0 launch was set for Sept 9, but with today‚Äôs Silksong news we‚Äôve made the tough call to postpone. A new date is coming soon, thank you all for the love and support ‚ù§Ô∏è pic.twitter.com/Lh07iGLHHn
‚Äî TALEGAMES (@Talegamesnews) August 21, 2025


Aeternum Game Studios, which is developing a 2D sidescrolling game focused on combat and exploration called Aeterna Lucis, is postponing a planned September release to sometime in 2026 because the game ‚Äúwouldn‚Äôt have the visibility it deserves.‚Äù Aeternum also says that it still doesn‚Äôt have the development kits to ‚Äúensure a simultaneous release on all next-generation platforms,‚Äù so the delay means it can ‚Äúbring you Aeterna Lucis at the right time.‚Äù


pic.twitter.com/CUomiRcsZU
‚Äî Aeternum Game Studios (@aeternathegame) August 22, 2025


Frogteam Games, which is working on the 2D exploration game Stomp and the Sword of Miracles, is delaying a planned August 29th demo launch, as spotted by Aftermath. ‚ÄúTrying to market an indie game is already really, really hard,‚Äù Frogteam Games says. It‚Äôs the task of trying to get attention in a deep sea of other amazing games. In the case of Silksong, however, I feel like a little krill trying to not get eaten by a blue whale. Tiny devs like me rely on word of mouth and streamers to bring in visibility, and everyone‚Äôs gonna be busy with Silksong for quite a while!


Head's up ‚Äì the Stomp demo has had to be suddenly delayed. I'll keep you all updated when I know what the plan is.
‚Äî Stomp and the Sword of Miracles (@frogteam.games) 2025-08-21T16:29:41.176Z


Even with these delays, early September is still packed with notable game releases, including Necrosoft Games‚Äôs Demonschool (September 3rd), Rogue Factor‚Äôs Hell is Us (September 4th), and Bloober Team‚Äôs Cronos: The New Dawn (September 5th). We‚Äôve reached out to the developers of those games to ask if they are changing their release plans because of Silksong.
Update, August 22nd: Added the delay for the demo of Stomp and the Sword of Miracles.

items.title: UN agency says Gaza famine is direct result of Israel‚Äôs actions and may amount to war crime ‚Äì as it happened
items.raw:
This blog is now closed, you can read more on this story here
Mothers in Gaza have resorted to using legume water and herbs as alternative to infant milk amid Famine, charity warns
Dr. Ra‚Äôed Al-Baba, who works at Al Awda Hospital run by ActionAid‚Äôs partner Al-Awda, said usage of alternatives to infant milk had ‚Äúcatastrophic‚Äù consequences.
There are mothers who resort to using legume water, herbs, and other alternatives to infant milk because of the severe shortage. These methods carry catastrophic risks, causing gastroenteritis, food poisoning, delayed growth, severe anaemia, and even the inability to move. We have seen cases of extreme dehydration from polluted water mixed with these substitutes. This is not survival, this is slow death.‚Äù
 Continue reading...

items.title: GYG shares: Guzman y Gomez plummets on ASX but expansion still on the menu as increased US losses rattle investors
items.raw:
GYG shares plummet by more than 20% on ASX despite global sales in the Sydney-based restaurant chain passing $1bn, as co-CEOs say ‚Äòwe are seeing momentum‚Äô in American market

Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

Mexican-themed chain Guzman y Gomez plans to open at least 15 restaurants in the US despite doubling its losses on its ‚Äúrelentless‚Äù bid to expand into the competitive American market.
Despite its struggles in the US, GYG recorded more than $1bn in sales across its network for the first time and more than doubled its net profit to $14.5m in the 12 months to July ‚Äì its first year on the Australian Stock Exchange (ASX).
 Continue reading...

items.title: Eswatini government faces court challenge over men deported by US
items.raw:
Group of NGOs claim deal was unconstitutional and violated the imprisoned men‚Äôs human rights
A group of NGOs is challenging Eswatini‚Äôs acceptance of five people deported by the US, arguing the deal was unconstitutional and violated the imprisoned men‚Äôs human rights.
The men from Vietnam, Jamaica, Laos, Yemen and Cuba, who the US said were dangerous criminals, were flown to the small southern African country in July, as the Trump administration attempts to deport millions of migrants and asylum seekers.
 Continue reading...

items.title: ‚ÄòI‚Äôm not against development, but ‚Ä¶‚Äô: Sydney‚Äôs plans for greater density face a morass of confusion and hostility
items.raw:
NSW has big plans to encourage more properties to be built, but it‚Äôs far from easy to satisfy councils, planning experts, residents and would-be residents

Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

Almost everyone agrees that Australia needs more housing, and nowhere more so than in Sydney, which has struggled to escape its reputation as one of the most expensive cities in the world to find somewhere to live.
The New South Wales planning minister, Paul Scully, says the problem of housing supply has been ignored for far too long.
 Continue reading...

items.title: UN-backed experts declare famine in and around Gaza City
items.raw:
IPC says famine is ‚Äòentirely man-made‚Äô and immediate response is needed or avoidable deaths will soar

Israel-Gaza war ‚Äì latest updates

An ‚Äúentirely man-made‚Äù famine is taking place in Gaza‚Äôs largest city and its surrounding area amid deteriorating conditions that threaten an exponential increase in deaths across the devastated territory, UN-backed experts have declared.
The Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC), a globally recognised organisation that classifies the severity of food insecurity and malnutrition, found that three key thresholds for famine had been met, signalling a major escalation of the humanitarian crisis in Gaza.
 Continue reading...

items.title: No Putin-Zelenskyy meeting planned until agenda is agreed, Russia‚Äôs foreign minister says ‚Äì as it happened
items.raw:
This blog is now closed
Speaking alongside Zelenskyy, Nato‚Äôs Rutte said the alliance‚Äôs support for Ukraine remained ‚Äúunwavering‚Äù and ‚Äúcontinues to grow,‚Äù with more plans to provide Nato funding to ensure ‚Äúa crucial flow of lethal US weapons to Ukraine.‚Äù
He lauded the outcome of Monday‚Äôs talks at the White House, saying that Trump made it clear ‚Äúthe United States will indeed be involved in providing security guarantees for Ukraine.‚Äù
‚ÄúRobust security guarantees will be essential, and this is what we are now working to define, so that when the time comes you for you to enter that bilateral meeting, you have the unmistakable force of Ukraine‚Äôs friends behind you, ensuring that Russia will uphold any deal, and will never ever again, attempt to take one square kilometre of Ukraine.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe Budapest Memorandum and Minsk did not provide those security guarantees. So we clearly know what it should not be, and we are now working together ‚Äì Ukraine, the Europeans, the United States ‚Äì to make sure that the security guarantees are of such a level that Vladimir Vladimirovich Putin, sitting in Moscow, will never, ever try to attack Ukraine again.‚Äù
 Continue reading...

items.title: Prigozhin knew he was ‚Äòdoomed‚Äô after failed rebellion, says mother
items.raw:
Violetta Prigozhina, 85, says she warned her son not to defy Putin‚Äôs authority before he was killed in a plane crash
The Russian warlord and businessman Yevgeny Prigozhin looked ‚Äúdoomed‚Äù after his failed mutiny and told his mother he expected to die in the days before his private plane crash.
Prigozhin, the founder of the notorious Wagner mercenary group, died when his business jet went down in the summer of 2023, two months after his fighters briefly seized control of the southern city of Rostov-on-Don and advanced towards Moscow in a short-lived rebellion against Russia‚Äôs military leadership.

items.title: Thousands face deportation to danger as Trump targets temporary protections
items.raw:
People with temporary protected status face possible deportation even though their home countries ‚Äì including Afghanistan and Haiti ‚Äì remain unsafe
Many thousands of immigrants living in the US who came from certain countries regarded as risky or dangerous are at the mercy of US judges and the Trump administration‚Äôs agenda to slash their work authorization and protection from deportation.
Since taking office, the Trump administration has announced the termination of temporary protected status (TPS) for citizens of seven of the 15 countries previously designated for shelter under this legal umbrella ‚Äì with the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) controversially citing improved conditions in some of those places.
 Continue reading...

items.title: Ukraine attacks pipeline that sends Russian oil to Hungary and Slovakia
items.raw:
Hungary‚Äôs foreign minister claims missile strike on energy infrastructure is ‚Äòanother attempt to drag us into war‚Äô
Ukraine has hit a key pumping station on the Druzhba oil pipeline bringing fuel to Europe from Russia, knocking out supplies to Hungary and Slovakia, the only remaining EU member states still receiving Russian oil.
As Ukraine targets infrastructure crucial to Moscow‚Äôs war effort in response to the Russian onslaught, the commander of Ukraine‚Äôs Unmanned Systems Forces, Robert Brovdi, announced the attack on the Unecha pumping station in the Bryansk region.
 Continue reading...

items.title: Belkin‚Äôs first 25W Qi2 chargers power up multiple devices
items.raw:
Belkin‚Äôs new wireless chargers will power up compatible phones much faster. | Image: Belkin	

After announcing certification from the Wireless Power Consortium (WPC) a month ago, Belkin is now debuting its first three devices that support the Qi2.2 standard and faster 25W wireless charging speeds.
The most expensive and elaborate of the new accessories is the $129.99 Belkin UltraCharge Pro 3-in-1 Magnetic Charging Dock, which is a multi-device wireless charger designed to find a permanent spot on desks and bedside tables.
It features an AirPods charger on its weighted base, an Apple Watch charger sticking out the back, and an adjustable magnetic smartphone charger in the front ‚Äì although that‚Äôs the only one that offers 25W charging speeds for supported devices. Wireless charging speeds will drop to 15W for devices that aren‚Äôt Qi2.2 compatible. A 45W USB-C power adapter is included so all three wireless charging pads can be used at the same time.
Slightly cheaper is the $99.99 Belkin UltraCharge 3-in-1 Foldable Magnetic Charger, which offers similar functionality to the Pro but in a design that completely folds flat for travel. Unfolding its magnetic 25W smartphone charger reveals a spot to charge AirPods on its base, while a compact Apple Watch charger folds out from behind its Qi2.2 pad.
It also comes with a 45W USB-C power adapter, and will be available in two versions: one with a squared-off design and an alternate with more rounded corners.
The $59.99 Belkin UltraCharge 2-in-1 Foldable Magnetic Charger is nearly identical to the 3-in-1 travel model but skips the pop-up Apple Watch charger. In its place is a 5W USB-C port on the base for plugging in the charging cable for other smartwatch models. It will also be available in two different designs and include a 45W power adapter.

items.title: Google made it easier to edit your Drive videos
items.raw:
Google has added a Drive shortcut for Workspace users that provides a quicker way to edit videos without having to manually open them in Google Vids. When previewing a video saved in their Drive, users will now see an ‚ÄúOpen‚Äù button at the top right corner that automatically opens the file in Google Vids, where users can then make simple edits like trimming clips, adding text or music, and more.
The Vids shortcut will be enabled by default and can be disabled by Workspace organization admins. It started rolling out on August 21st, but could take more than two weeks to appear for everyone. This is the latest of several  Drive improvements that Google has added for videos, having introduced a new video player in October last year, and a Gemini AI feature that summarizes Drive videos in May.

items.title: Google‚Äôs AI-stuffed Pixel 10 event
items.raw:
The Pixel line has often been on the cutting edge of mobile photography. This year, that means baking AI straight into the camera app and making us grapple with all of the very messy things that means. I've been scouring the internet for sample images of the Pixel 10 Pro's AI-enhanced 100x zoom feature - Pro Res Zoom - and the early results have been all over the place. There are early samples that look great and others that make me very worried about what Google has unleashed.
This week on The Vergecast, we're talking all things Pixel. Victoria Song and Allison Johnson join me to discuss the launch in detail, starting with the strange, key ‚Ä¶
Read the full story at The Verge.

items.title: Hundreds of TikTok UK moderator jobs at risk despite new online safety rules
items.raw:
Cuts in trust and safety team part of switch towards artificial intelligence by social media app firm
TikTok has put hundreds of UK content moderators‚Äô jobs at risk, even as tighter rules come into effect to stop the spread of harmful material online.
The viral video app said several hundred jobs in its trust and safety team could be affected in the UK, as well as south and south-east Asia, as part of a global reorganisation.
 Continue reading...

items.title: Netflix‚Äôs Long Story Short is a more human successor to BoJack Horseman
items.raw:
A big reason that BoJack Horseman worked so well was contrast. It took place in a silly world of talking animals, and used that to explore deep human drama in relatable ways. It's part of what made its oddball jokes work so well, as they helped balance out the darker moments that explored topics like mental health and addiction. The same could be said for its spiritual offshoot Tuca & Bertie, which ramped up the wackiness - sexy plant ladies, ghost cakes - but didn't shy away from getting real.
Now we have Long Story Short, which comes from much of the same creative team; it's led by BoJack creator Raphael Bob-Waksberg, while Tuca showrunne ‚Ä¶
Read the full story at The Verge.

items.title: Italian pizzeria owner praised for tracking down ‚Äòdine and dash‚Äô tourists

Michela Malatini used social media to trace two French women and presented them with their ‚Ç¨44 bill
An Italian pizzeria owner has been praised for her bravery after managing to track down a pair of ‚Äúdine and dash‚Äù tourists and handing them the bill.
The French women had enjoyed pizza and a few glasses of Aperol spritz at Ai Due Re pizzeria in Civitanova Marche, a town on the Adriatic coast, racking up a ‚Ç¨44 bill. But they left without paying.
 Continue reading...

items.title: Digg‚Äôs new app is basic, but a great start
items.raw:
Digg is making a comeback. With the backing of people like Digg cofounder Kevin Rose and Reddit cofounder Alexis Ohanian, Digg has ambitions to once again be the homepage of the internet. The revival is still in its very early days - the platform is still invite-only - but Digg launched its new mobile apps this week, and I installed the iOS app on my phone to see what it's like. 
New Digg operates similarly to Reddit: people submit links that others can comment and vote on, and links with a lot of "diggs" (upvotes) will bubble up the feed. You can also tap a downvote-like "bury" button, but on posts (not comments), the bury button functions ‚Ä¶
Read the full story at The Verge.

items.title: Google‚Äôs first Gemini smart home speaker detailed in leak
items.raw:
Google‚Äôs mystery new speaker appeared briefly in its keynote alongside F1 driver Lando Norris.	

Google announced plenty of new hardware at this week‚Äôs Made by Google event, but halfway through we were distracted by the brief appearance of what appeared to be a new, previously unknown Gemini-powered smart speaker. Now Android Headlines claims that this speaker is real, and will launch with new colors and the ability to pair with a Google TV Streamer.
Android Headlines reports that it‚Äôs seen additional images of the mystery speaker, which will apparently come in four colors: bright red, light green, black, and white. As seen briefly in the keynote video, it features a light around the base ‚Äî rather than across the top, as on previous Google speakers ‚Äî and a fabric finish.
As for features, the big new one is that the speaker will apparently be able to pair with a Google TV Streamer to deliver spatial TV audio, a trick borrowed from Apple‚Äôs HomePods, which can connect to Apple TV hardware. Hopefully it can also connect to TVs that run the Google TV OS. It will apparently also include new natural voice options, the ability to detect unusual sounds like glass breaking or a smoke alarm, and full support for Matter.
Gemini will deliver the smarts, rather than Google Assistant, which is no surprise. The company announced Gemini for Home this week, which will arrive on existing Nest smart speakers and displays from October this year. It will include a paid tier and support for Gemini Live, though it‚Äôs not clear which features will be gated behind the premium subscription.
Android Headlines calls the new hardware the ‚ÄúHome Speaker,‚Äù though it‚Äôs not clear if that‚Äôs its full or final name. We also don‚Äôt know when it will be released, though a launch alongside Gemini for Home in the fall seems likely. We‚Äôd expect to see an updated smart display before long too, since Google hasn‚Äôt updated its Nest Hub line since 2021, and we‚Äôve already found that Amazon‚Äôs new Alexa Plus works best on devices with screens.

items.title: Trump Mobile‚Äôs fake iPhone is now a fake S25 Ultra
items.raw:
The T1 Phone (left) looks uncannily like the S25 Ultra in a Spigen Thin Fit case (right).	

When Trump Mobile first unveiled the T1 Phone, we were confused by the mixed marketing, which included dubious renders of what at least appeared to be an original phone along with multiple appearances from what was quite clearly a gold-plated iPhone. Now we can add Samsung‚Äôs Galaxy S25 Ultra into the mix.
The Trump Mobile team shared an ad to X on Wednesday pushing preorders of the T1, but with an image we‚Äôd never seen before. You don‚Äôt have to look hard to realize that this is an S25 Ultra that‚Äôs been Photoshopped gold with a T1 logo and US flag; looking a little closer confirms that it‚Äôs a render of that phone in a Spigen case, right down to the Spigen logo they didn‚Äôt bother to remove. 
It‚Äôs a remarkable choice because the S25 Ultra looks even less like the T1 Phone‚Äôs official renders than the iPhone the company has previously used in promotions. Even Spigen noticed the dupe, saying what we‚Äôre all thinking in its reply on X: ‚Äú??? bro what‚Äù
The new X post promises that ‚ÄúThe wait is almost over!‚Äù for the T1 Phone, which originally advertised launch dates of August and September (one in the press release, the other on the site), but now lists no date at all. The company also no longer claims the phone will be made in the USA, instead saying there are ‚ÄúAmerican hands behind every device.‚Äù The phone has shrunk dramatically since launch too, now promising a 6.25-inch screen, way down from the 6.78-inch display described when it was first announced.

items.title: These programs help poor students with college. Trump wants to pull the funding

items.title: Largest retailers in the U.S. have raised prices on some items

items.title: Florida man orders beautification of America after gold-plating the White House
items.raw:
We can only hope that Trump keeps his own aesthetic preferences out of it. | Image: Bloomberg via Getty Images	

President Donald Trump signed a new executive order on Thursday to improve the ‚Äúusability and aesthetics‚Äù of US government services by creating ‚Äúfirst-class online and offline experiences for Americans.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt is time to update the Government‚Äôs design language to be both usable and beautiful,‚Äù Trump said in the order, which establishes an America by Design initiative meant to ‚Äúimprove comprehensively the visual presentation and usability of Federal services provided to the public in both digital and physical spaces.‚Äù 
A new National Design Studio is being set up to facilitate this, led by a chief design officer ‚Äî with Airbnb co-founder Joe Gebbia reportedly lined up for the position, according to Reuters.
Gebbia has already been tasked with overhauling the sluggishly paper-based federal retirement process after joining Trump‚Äôs DOGE service in February. It‚Äôs unclear what direction Gebbia‚Äôs design choices will take, but here‚Äôs hoping he isn‚Äôt too influenced by Trump‚Äôs love for all things golden, gaudy, and gilded. Refraining from randomly capitalizing text would also be a bonus.

items.title: Travellers warned of bank holiday disruption
items.raw: A rail strike and works are expected this weekend as millions begin their bank holiday getaways.

items.title: Flower girls and bridesmaids ‚Äì the dogs playing a starring role in weddings
items.raw: Many couples are including their pet in their big day, we talk to some whose dogs have played a key role.

items.title: Peter Dutton rules out return to politics in rare public appearance ‚Äì as it happened
items.raw:
This blog is now closed.
Coalition says if Labor tries to raise taxes after roundtable it would be ‚Äòmajor breach of faith‚Äô with Australian people
James Paterson, the shadow minister for finance, says if the government moves to increase taxes it would be a ‚Äúmajor breach of faith with the Australian people‚Äù. Paterson spoke to RN Breakfast after the conclusion of yesterday‚Äôs roundtable, where Chalmers said there was a longer-term process to consider major reform on the matter.
No Australian voted for higher taxes at the election, and so it seems that Jim Chalmers isn‚Äôt on the same page as the prime minister because he was unwilling to repeat that commitment at his press conference yesterday. And he is leaving open the door to higher taxes, and particularly on people‚Äôs retirement savings, on family trusts, on a whole range of other things.
When those questions were raised during the election campaign, Jim Chalmers and the Labor party said that was a Liberal Party scare campaign. So, if they go ahead and try and increase taxes, that‚Äôll be a major breach of faith with the Australian people.
 Continue reading...

The infant‚Äôs mother, in her 30s, had been assisting police with enquiries since Wednesday

Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

A woman has been charged with concealing the birth of a deceased child after the body of a baby boy was found in a storm water drain in Perth.
The woman, in her 30s, had been assisting police with enquiries since Wednesday following the discovery of the infant on Monday afternoon.

items.title: Outback Wrangler star agreed helicopter pilot had ‚Äòthrown everyone under the bus‚Äô in covert recording played in court
items.raw:
Matt Wright has pleaded not guilty to three counts of attempting to pervert the course of justice

Follow our Australia news live blog for latest updates

Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

The reality TV star Matt Wright‚Äôs home was bugged with listening devices and phone taps for three months as police sought evidence of a cover-up following a fatal helicopter crash, a jury has heard.
Covert recordings of Wright‚Äôs conversations have played a key part in his trial at the Northern Territory supreme court in Darwin.

items.title: Friday briefing: Is Israel‚Äôs plan for Gaza City a full-scale assault ‚Äì or political theatre?
items.raw:
In today‚Äôs newsletter: After Israeli officials announced a stepped-up military operation in the city, Palestinians and the world wait to see what happens next

Good morning. Israel claims to have launched the first stages of a sweeping military operation to conquer Gaza City ‚Äì the administrative heart of the strip ‚Äì warning that a million people could be forced from their homes, sparking a wave of fear among residents.
In the past few nights Palestinians have described relentless bombardments, with thousands already scrambling to escape, while others are too starved or frail to evacuate.
UK news | Protesters at the next mass demonstration against the ban on Palestine Action will withhold their details from officers to force en-masse processing at police stations in an effort to make it ‚Äúpractically impossible‚Äù to arrest everyone.
Ukraine | Moscow threw Donald Trump‚Äôs Ukraine peace initiative into disarray on Thursday, insisting it must have a veto over any postwar support for the country as its forces carried out a large-scale overnight missile barrage.
Immigration | Refugee support organisations have been forced to install safe rooms in their premises, relocate to less visible sites and in some cases close their offices in response to the threat of far-right violence, the Guardian can reveal.
US news | A federal judge in Miami late on Thursday ordered the closure of the Trump administration‚Äôs notorious ‚ÄúAlligator Alcatraz‚Äù immigration jail within 60 days and ruled that no more detainees were to be brought to the facility while it was being wound down.
Health | Baby food manufacturers have been given 18 months to improve the quality of their products in England amid mounting concerns that leading brands are nutritionally poor.
 Continue reading...

items.title: Thailand former PM cleared of royal insult charge but Shinawatra dynasty‚Äôs fate still hangs in balance
items.raw:
Lese-majesty case against Thaksin Shinawatra is dismissed, but his daughter Paetongtarn will hear next week if she will be removed as prime minster
A criminal court in Thailand has dismissed a case accusing former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra of defaming the monarchy, the first of three court cases that could decide the fate of one of the country‚Äôs prominent political families.
Thaksin was accused of insulting the monarchy during an interview with South Korean newspaper Chosun Ilbo in 2015.

items.title: Indonesia working on details of plan to treat 2,000 people from Gaza amid concerns about right to return
items.raw:
Security ministry and the ministries of health and foreign affairs have met to discuss how the controversial proposal to treat Palestinians would work
The Indonesian government is working on plans to treat 2,000 people from war-ravaged Gaza, holding a series of inter-ministerial discussions to discuss logistics, legality and foreign policy implications relating to the highly sensitive proposal, according to a senior government official.
Indonesia announced earlier this month that it would provide temporary medical assistance to 2,000 Palestinians from Gaza, with the uninhabited island of Galang identified as one possible site. Located just south of Singapore, the island was once home to a former camp for Vietnamese refugees and most recently the site of a pandemic hospital.
 Continue reading...

items.title: UN and Red Cross warn of catastrophe if Israel launches Gaza City offensive
items.raw:
Netanyahu tells soldiers he has approved takeover plan as aid groups advised to prepare for forced displacement
The International Red Cross and UN have warned of an impending catastrophe in the Gaza Strip if Israel launches an offensive to take over Gaza City, as the Israeli military told medical and aid groups in the Palestinian territory to prepare for imminent forced displacement.
At the same time a concerted campaign of international opposition to Israel‚Äôs defiance of ceasefire calls and its approval of a huge new illegal settlement construction in the occupied West Bank gathered pace, with the UK summoning Israel‚Äôs ambassador and joining 20 other countries in condemning the settlement plan as a ‚Äúviolation of international law‚Äù.
 Continue reading...

items.title: Has Israel begun its Gaza City offensive or will there be yet more ‚Äòapprovals‚Äô?
items.raw:
Netanyahu is latest to ‚Äòapprove‚Äô plan that has had daily announcements and that Israel knows will have serious consequences
Has Israel begun its expanded offensive in Gaza City, or is it hype?
After several weeks of threats of a new large-scale offensive, strongly opposed by most of the international community, Israeli officials have made announcements daily saying the plan to occupy Gaza City has been ‚Äúapproved‚Äù; it has been approved by the Israel Defense Forces, by the security cabinet, by the defence minister.

items.title: Bolsonaro given 48 hours to explain alleged plans to flee to Argentina
items.raw:
Brazilian supreme court judge sets ultimatum after police claim far-right populist sought to flee to avoid punishment over failed coup
A supreme court judge has given Brazil‚Äôs ex-president, Jair Bolsonaro, 48 hours to explain police claims he was planning to flee to Argentina to avoid punishment for allegedly masterminding a failed coup after losing the 2022 election.
Bolsonaro‚Äôs trial for the alleged attempt to seize power is scheduled to conclude early next month. The far-right populist faces more than four decades in prison if found guilty.
 Continue reading...

items.title: Uganda reaches agreement with US to take in some failed asylum seekers
items.raw:
African country‚Äôs foreign ministry says the two states are working on the details of a deal over deportees
Uganda has reached an agreement with the US to take in deportees from third countries who may not get asylum but are ‚Äúreluctant‚Äù to go back to their own countries, according to Uganda‚Äôs foreign ministry.
The country will not accept people with criminal records or unaccompanied minors under the temporary arrangement, ‚Äã‚Äãthe Ugandan foreign ministry‚Äôs permanent secretary said in a statement. He did not say whether Uganda was receiving any payment or other benefits and how many deportees it would accept.
 Continue reading...

items.raw: Canadian residents made just 1.7 million return trips by motor vehicle back into their country from the U.S. in July, a nearly 37% decline over the same month in 2024, according to Statistics Canada.

items.raw: Rapha√´l Graven, also known as Jean Pormanove, was found dead at a residence in Contes, a village north of Nice, prosecutors said.

items.title: Pressure grows on Tanzania to free victim of domestic violence who has been on death row for 13 years
items.raw:
Lemi Limbu, who was convicted of murdering her daughter, has severe intellectual disabilities and ‚Äòabsolutely should not be in prison‚Äô, say campaigners
Pressure is mounting on the Tanzanian government to release a woman with severe intellectual disabilities who has been in prison awaiting execution for 13 years.
Lemi Limbu, who is now in her early 30s, was convicted of the murder of her daughter in 2015. A survivor of brutal and repeated sexual and domestic violence, she has the developmental age of a child.
 Continue reading...

items.title: New Zealand to spend $3bn upgrading helicopters and ‚Äòembarrassing‚Äô defence planes
items.raw:
Government says country will buy five Seahawk helicopters and two Airbus A321XLR aircraft
New Zealand will spend nearly NZ$3bn ($1.7bn) upgrading its ageing defence fleet, including replacing its ‚Äúembarrassing‚Äù planes that have left multiple prime ministers grounded during international travel, the government has announced.
The defence minister, Judith Collins, said NZ$2bn would be spent buying five MH-60R Seahawk helicopters and another NZ$700m to buy two Airbus A321XLR aircraft.
 Continue reading...

items.title: Brazil police file court documents accusing Bolsonaro of planning to flee to Argentina to seek asylum
items.raw:
Brazil‚Äôs former president is accused of allegedly plotting a military coup, but he denies the charges
Brazilian police have claimed in court documents that they have found a document on the mobile phone of former president Jair Bolsonaro suggesting he had planned to flee to Argentina ahead of his judgment for allegedly plotting a military coup.
The far-right populist is facing a jail term of over 40 years when Brazil‚Äôs supreme court convenes next month to decide whether he is guilty of conspiring to overturn the result of the 2022 presidential election, which Bolsonaro lost to his leftwing opponent Luiz In√°cio Lula da Silva.
 Continue reading...

items.title: US court allows Trump officials to end protected status for 60,000 migrants
items.raw:
Administration officials given legal right to move towards deportation of people from Nepal, Honduras and Nicaragua
A federal appeals court on Wednesday sided with the Trump administration and halted for now a lower court‚Äôs order that had kept in place temporary protections for 60,000 migrants from Central America and Nepal.
This means that the Republican administration can move toward removing an estimated 7,000 people from Nepal whose temporary protected status designations expired on 5 August. The TPS designations and legal status of 51,000 Hondurans and 3,000 Nicaraguans are set to expire 8 September, at which point they will become eligible for removal.
 Continue reading...

items.title: India ‚Äòsuccessfully tests‚Äô nuclear-capable missile able to reach deep into China
items.raw:
Agni-5 intermediate-range ballistic missile also part of Narendra Modi‚Äôs defence strategy against Pakistan
India has said it successfully test-fired an intermediate-range ballistic missile that, when operational, should be capable of carrying a nuclear warhead to any part of China.
The Agni-5 missile was successfully launched in India‚Äôs eastern Odisha state on Wednesday, and authorities said it ‚Äúvalidated all operational and technical parameters‚Äù.
 Continue reading...

items.title: Microsoft boss troubled by rise in reports of 'AI psychosis'
items.raw: Mustafa Suleyman said there was still "zero evidence of AI consciousness today".

items.title: Human rights regulator criticises Met's use of facial recognition cameras

items.title: South African minister investigated for historical racial slurs on social media
items.raw:
Gayton McKenzie given deadline to apologise, undergo sensitivity training and delete posts 
South Africa‚Äôs sport, arts and culture minister, Gayton McKenzie, is under investigation by the country‚Äôs human rights commission for historical social media posts containing a highly offensive racial slur, reigniting a debate about racism, identity and the lingering effects of colonialism and apartheid.
McKenzie, an anti-immigrant populist from the Coloured community with a history of stirring up controversies, was given a Wednesday evening deadline by the South African Human Rights Commission (SAHRC) to issue an approved apology, undergo sensitivity training, donate to an agreed charity and delete the X posts, which were still online at the time of publication.
 Continue reading...

items.title: Supporting freedom of expression is not wrong, Jimmy Lai‚Äôs lawyer tells court
items.raw:
Closing arguments made in Hong Kong media mogul‚Äôs national security trial, which has lasted more than 140 days
A lawyer for Jimmy Lai has argued that it is not wrong to support freedom of expression, as he began his final argument in the prominent Hong Kong democracy activist and newspaper founder‚Äôs landmark national security trial.
The barrister Robert Pang is representing Lai in his fight against charges of colluding with foreign forces to endanger national security and conspiring with others to issue seditious publications. Lai, 77, faces up to life in prison if convicted under a national security law imposed by Beijing after anti-government protests in 2019.
 Continue reading...

items.title: Uganda denies reports that it has struck deal with Trump to take in US deportees
items.raw:
Ugandan official said the east African country does not have the capability to take in undocumented immigrants
Uganda said it has not reached any agreement with the US to take in undocumented immigrants, contradicting reports that the east African country had struck a deal with the Trump administration to do so.
Henry Oryem Okello, Uganda‚Äôs state minister for foreign affairs, told Reuters the country does not have the capability to take in immigrants. It comes as the US has deported migrants convicted of crimes in the US to non-native countries including South Sudan and Eswatini.
 Continue reading...

items.title: Watch final trip for church on wheels as it moves to new home
items.raw: It took two days to move the church in Sweden's Kiruna, which was at risk at risk from ground subsidence.

items.title: These brain implants speak your mind ‚Äî even when you don't want to

items.title: Peruvian woman accused of trying to smuggle cocaine into Bali using sex toy
items.raw:
Officers say they found 1.4kg of drug inside toy in woman‚Äôs underwear and also accused her of hiding ecstasy pills
A Peruvian woman has been arrested in Bali after allegedly trying to smuggle cocaine into the Indonesian resort island using a sex toy and hiding drugs in her underwear, police said.
The 42-year-old, identified only by her initials NS, arrived at Bali‚Äôs international airport from Qatar on 12 August when authorities became suspicious.
 Continue reading...

items.title: Research suggests doctors might quickly become dependent on AI
items.raw: A study in Poland found that doctors appeared less likely to detect abnormalities during colonoscopies on their own after they'd grown used to help from an AI tool.

items.title: An AI divide is growing in schools. This camp wants to level the playing field
items.raw: For years, research has shown a digital divide when it comes to schools teaching about new technologies. Educators worry that this could leave some students behind in an AI-powered economy.

items.title: Stop children using VPNs to watch porn, ministers told
items.raw: The children's commissioner for England tells the BBC virtual private networks are a "loophole that needs closing.

items.title: Intel shares jump as Softbank to buy $2bn stake in chip giant
items.raw: The announcement comes hours after reports that the White House is in talks over taking a 10% stake in Intel.

items.title: Meta investigated over AI having 'sensual' chats with children
items.raw: The leak has led to backlash amid reports the tech giant's legal staff approved the conversations.

items.title: What's behind the Trump administration's immigration memes?
items.raw: White supremacist tropes and ironic viral jokes illustrate the administration's project of redefining who belongs in the United States.

items.title: Should Europe wean itself off US tech?
items.raw: Just three US firms provide 70% of Europe's cloud-computing, leading to fears of overreliance.

items.title: AI is driving a data center boom in rural America. Locals are divided on the benefits
items.raw: Artificial intelligence is driving a data center building boom across rural America, including in central Washington. But critics say the centers do not produce enough jobs ‚Äî and drain resources.

items.title: Class-action suit claims Otter AI secretly records private work conversations
items.raw: The suit claims the popular service may be recording and processing millions of users' private conversations without consent.

items.title: Brain implants that decode a person's inner voice may threaten privacy
items.raw: A new brain-computer interface can decode a person's inner monologue. That could help paralyzed people communicate, but also suggests scientists are one step closer to reading a person's thoughts.

items.title: VW introduces monthly subscription to increase car power
items.raw: The German car-maker says its "optional power upgrade" is designed to give customers more choice.

items.title: UK's Turing AI Institute responds to staff anger about defence focus
items.raw: Whistleblowers say the charity is at risk of collapse because it has been told by the government to focus on defence.

items.title: Data centres to be expanded across UK as concerns mount
items.raw: The number of data centres is set to jump by a fifth in the coming years, figures seen by the BBC suggest.

items.title: Intel shares jump after report of possible US stake in chipmaker
items.raw: The reports emerged a day after a meeting between the Intel boss and Donald Trump.

items.title: Angry, confused and worried about police ‚Äì behind Instagram bans
items.raw: Hundreds of people have contacted the BBC to say they have wrongly been shut out of their accounts.

items.title: A summer camp aims to close the AI know-how gap for low-income high schoolers
items.raw: A free camp for low-income high schoolers aims to close the digital divide around AI know-how. Campers work on AI solutions to real-world environmental and medical challenges.

items.title: Anti-Trump podcast MeidasTouch is rivaling Joe Rogan. Does it have staying power?
items.raw: The left-leaning media outfit has surged in Donald Trump's second term, appealing to progressives outraged by the president. Still, the online streaming world remains dominated by right-wing voices.

items.title: Firm apologises for saying it would not process LGBTQ+ payments
items.raw: Stripe said the information given by its support staff to some customers was "totally wrong."

items.title: Government expands police use of facial recognition vans
items.raw: The Home Office says the technology helps locate suspects but civil liberties groups warn of heightened surveillance.

items.title: Porn site traffic plummets as UK age verification rules enforced
items.raw: Data suggests leading adult site Pornhub lost more than one million visitors in two weeks.

items.title: Bezos-backed Perplexity AI makes surprise bid for Google Chrome
items.raw: One technology investor called the $34.5bn offer a "stunt" that is much lower than Chrome's true value.

items.title: AI can make us UK's biggest firm, Rolls-Royce says
items.raw: Tufan Erginbilgic says business deals to supply nuclear power for artificial intelligence could boost its fortunes

items.title: Apple rejects Musk's App Store bias claims
items.raw: The X owner had accused Apple of making it impossible to fairly compete with ChatGPT.

items.title: 'Cryptocrash king' Do Kwon pleads guilty to fraud
items.raw: The South Korean former tech executive co-founded Singapore-based cryptocurrency firm Terraform Labs.

items.title: It shocked the market but has China's DeepSeek changed AI?
items.raw: Some six months after DeepSeek shook Silicon Valley, is the Chinese AI chatbot still relevant?
